docs.lead_paragraph: A closely watched gauge of future business activity fell in August for a third consecutive month, evidence that companies and consumers continue to face an uncertain economic climate. In a separate report, more Americans than expected filed new claims for unemployment benefits last week, after a third hurricane hit Florida. The Conference Board said yesterday that its Composite Index of Leading Economic Indicators fell 0.3 percent in August to 115.7, after a decline of 0.3 percent in July.

headline.main: Jobless Claims Up in August; Economic Indicators Fall

docs.abstract: Conference Board says its Composite Index of Leading Economic Indicators fell 0.3 percent in August to 115.7, after decline of 0.3 percent in July; Labor Department reports number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance rose by seasonally adjusted 14,000, to 350,000, mostly result of Florida hurricanes; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 32-year-old woman in Belgium has become the first woman ever to give birth after having ovarian tissue removed, frozen and then implanted back in her body, doctors are reporting. The patient had the tissue removed in 1997 in hopes of preserving her fertility because she had Hodgkin's lymphoma, a type of cancer, and was about to undergo chemotherapy with drugs likely to damage her ovaries and cause infertility. She and her doctors hoped that once she was cured, the ovarian tissue could be thawed and returned to her abdomen to produce eggs.

headline.main: Report of First Birth For Cancer Survivor In a Tissue Implant

docs.abstract: Healthy baby is born to woman in Belgium who, as cancer patient, had ovarian tissue removed, frozen and then implanted back in her body; patient had tissue removed in 1997 in hopes of preserving her fertility as she was about to undergo chemotherapy with drugs likely to damage her ovaries and cause infertility; case reflects success story in cancer treatment: cure rates for cancers in children and young people have increased enough to make it realistic to worry about whether survivors will be able to have children of their own in future; medical team in Brussels writes that their ovary-freezing technique should be offered to all young cancer patients who must undergo treatment that might leave them infertile; report is published in The Lancet, British medical journal; other experts in field say procedure, which must still be considered experimental, is not only option, and not neessarily best option, for all girls and women (M)
docs.snippet: A 32-year-old woman in Belgium has become the first woman ever to give birth after having ovarian tissue removed, frozen and then implanted back in her body.

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers at two Hershey Foods Corporation plants rejected a contract extension that would have forced them to pay more for health care benefits and accept lower wages for less-senior employees. The results, tallied Wednesday after two days of voting, were 1,259 to 801 against the proposal to extend the Chocolate Workers Local 464 contract through 2008. The pact would have raised employees' health care contributions from 6 percent to 12 percent, beginning in January 2006. The union will continue to work under the current contract, which covers 2,700 employees and expires in November 2005, officials said. The proposed contract extension would also have reduced wages by $4 an hour for nearly 260 employees hired after January 2000. It also called for annual raises of 2 percent and improved dental, vision and retirement plans.

headline.main: WORKERS AT HERSHEY PLANTS REJECT CONTRACT PROPOSAL

docs.abstract: Workers at two Hershey Foods Corp plants reject contract extension that would have forced them to pay more health care benefits and accept lower wages for less-senior employees; will continue to work under current contract, which expires in November 2005 (S)
docs.snippet: Workers at two Hershey Foods Corporation plants rejected a contract extension that would have forced them to pay more for health care benefits and accept lower wages for less-senior employees. The results, tallied Wednesday after two days of voting,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for Hollywood producers agreed to increase health care payments for directors but did not raise payments for DVD sales and rentals in a new three-year contract reached Thursday. The Directors Guild of America is the first of three Hollywood labor unions to reach a new contract. The agreement, which is subject to approval by guild members, was expected to set the tone for negotiations with writers and actors.

headline.main: Directors Agree on Contract With Hollywood Producers

docs.abstract: Directors Guild of America reaches three-year labor agreement with Hollywood producers that increases health care payments for directors but does not raise payments for DVD sales and rentals; agreement is expected to set tone for talks with writers and actors (M)
docs.snippet: Negotiators for Hollywood producers agreed to increase health care payments for directors but did not raise payments for DVD sales and rentals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since the government announced this month that Medicare premiums would rise 17.4 percent next year, the largest annual monthly increase ever, Senator John Kerry has blamed President Bush for increasing what retirees have to pay for their health insurance. Bush took office.

docs.lead_paragraph: Unable to resolve a contract dispute over health insurance, thousands of janitors and doormen voted yesterday to authorize a strike beginning next Friday at 1,000 New York City office buildings. Michael Fishman, president of the janitors' union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said union leaders had asked for a strike authorization vote because a significant gap remained in negotiations.

headline.main: Office Building Janitors Back a Strike Over Health Plan Cost

docs.abstract: Thousands of janitors and doormen authorize strike at 1,000 New York City office buildings; photo; contract talks snag on health insurance (S)
docs.snippet: Unable to resolve a contract dispute over health insurance, thousands of janitors and doormen voted yesterday to authorize a strike beginning next Friday at 1,000 New York City office buildings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some ideas sound so deliciously awful (I know: let's do ''E.R.: Las Vegas'') that it is boorish to mock them. Casting Rob Lowe as an idealistic doctor who hangs his shingle in a casino comes very close. But ''Dr. Vegas,'' which starts tonight on CBS, turns out to be kind of fun -- kino cards and colonoscopies do mix. Mr. Lowe plays Billy Grant, a good-hearted emergency- room doctor with a bad gambling habit. His friend Tommy, played by Joe Pantoliano, a casino general manager, hires Billy as the in-house doctor; Billy turns a penthouse suite into a fully equipped emergency room and recruits a conscientious emergency room colleague, Alice (Amy Adams), as his nurse and scold-in-residence.

headline.main: Rob Lowe Bets On His Wild Side

docs.abstract: Alessandra Stanley reviews new CBS series Dr Vegas, starring Rob Lowe; photos (M)
docs.snippet: CBS's new drama starring Mr. Lowe as a a good-hearted doctor with a gambling habit, turns out to be kind of fun  kino cards and colonoscopies do mix.

docs.lead_paragraph: John Kerry woos them, but perhaps not enough. George W. Bush does too, and even Laura Bush. Even so, small-business owners rarely make headlines as a political target group even though they are as many as 25 million strong and a major generator of jobs.
docs.abstract: Presidential candidate George W Bush and John Kerry are wooing 25-million small business owners; Bush campaign has zeroed in on small-business owners, with Bush pushing his programs for tax relief, lower health care costs and litigation reform; Kerry is hoping to make some inroads on health care costs, access to capital and tax relief; small-business owners are still likely to favor Bush by big margin over Kerry; National Association of Women Business Owners survey shows 55.9 percent of its members queried in August supported Kerry versus 40.1 percent for Bush; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The presidential candidates are paying attention to entrepreneurs.

docs.lead_paragraph: If freedom of expression has limits in Canada, Jean-François Fillion is testing them as the radio shock jock whom both federal regulators and Quebec separatists want to silence. On one of his recent early morning talk shows on the hard rock station CHOI-FM, he intimated that ''there is a lesbian in every woman.'' He suggested -- half-jokingly, but without substantiation -- that the mayor of Quebec City, Jean-Paul L'Allier, was ''probably a drunk, and nobody is aware of this.'' Mr. Fillion, 37, chastised left-wing Quebecers for celebrating the latest Palestinian suicide bombings, though there is no evidence that they did.

headline.main: Bad Mouth or Free Mouth, He Ruffles Genteel Airwaves

docs.abstract: Highest-rated radio talk host on Quebec radio is Jean-Francois Fillion, shock-jock whose gossip about politicians and competing radio personalities is often abusive and unsubstantiated; when federal authorities tried to close his station for remarks he and his sidekicks made on air, 200,000 people signed petitions saying closing of station was attack on freedom of expression; authorities relented; photo of thousands of demonstrators demanding that Canadian broadcast commission renew his station's license; photo (M)
docs.snippet: If freedom of expression has limits in Canada, Jean-François Fillion, a radio shock jock, is testing them.
